This is from third album titled ""Myth Takes."" And the band has to get creative to record it.
See, the band members live thousands of miles apart -more on that in a minute.
came through Washington this week and we hopped on their tour bus to have a chat.
It's a big bus but for nine band members, sleeping bunks line the sides, floor to ceiling, and in back, stray vocalists and percussionists sprawl in the leather couch watching television.
For this interview, we settled on just two of the band members, singer Nic Offer and guitarist Mario Andreoni.
And the first question, always the first question with this band is about the name.
is actually written exclamation point, exclamation point, exclamation point.
It doesn't exactly roll off the tongue.
(Soundbite of laughter)
The - you...
First, the numbers.
About four in 10 families in Cook County - that's City of Chicago - plus a number of surrounding suburbs are renters.
They have about 835,000 rental homes to choose from.
And Susanne Cannon, the head of the real estate center at DePaul University says only about a third of those units are considered affordable.
By that, we mean affordable to a family of four making $30,000 a year or less, which means that it would rent for about $750 a month or less.
So the Urban Land Institute, the MacArthur Foundation and others have set up a rental housing action plan they call the Preservation Compact.
Under the plan, a developer looking to buy or fix up affordable rental units will be able to get a low cost loan or grant from a $100 million fund.
Julia Stasch, a former Chicago housing commissioner, now at MacArthur, says the foundation is providing the seed money.
If buyers can't act quickly when affordable properties are offered for sale, affordable units are lost.
If troubled buildings can't be stabilized, refinanced and then sold to responsible preservation owners, then buildings, again, can be lost.
If current owners can't keep their properties well maintained and affordable, then once again, there's a likelihood that these buildings can be lost.
That's all good, says Mabel Guzman, a director with the Chicago Association of Realtors, if neighborhoods, landlords and tenants all agree that affordable rentals are an asset.

But I think they're opposed to it in some communities where they feel we have enough, and we really want to see more homeowners coming in because, generally, I would - the belief is that homeowners truly have a vested interest in the community.
Many people think everybody should be a homeowner, but that's not going to happen.
DePaul's Susanne Cannon says the country has done a remarkable job of moving people to homeownership.
What we need to understand is that there is always going to be a demand for rental and that we're in danger of losing affordable rental housing.
Can you show me around?
Yeah, sure.
This is my younger son, Shawn.
Myra Consosolo shows off her apartment, a two-bedroom place she has lived in with her two sons for about 10 years.
Consosolo makes $28,000 a year and pays a third of her income in rent.
There are lots of condos in Logan Square now and housing prices has skyrocketed.
When the owner opted to sell the Lorrington Apartments when the building's federal subsidy ended, Consosolo and other residents worked with the neighborhood group to find a new buyer and financing.
Consosolo said it was crucial to keep the Lorrington's 54 units in the neighborhood at a cost its residents could afford.
What I'm saying is if I'm the one who work full time and is still going to make it, imagine the other people who are elderly.
Most of all, hey, I want a place for my sons to be able to stay.
I don't think it's fair that they're just being kicked out because the neighborhood is nice.
Cheryl Corley, NPR News, Chicago.
A young scientist struggling with his experiments suddenly comes up with some startling results.
A colleague is suspicious.
Are the data too good to be true?
Allegra Goodman's new novel Intuition explores the tense relations between researchers and a cancer lab and the professional passions that drive them.
NPR's science correspondent Joe Palca spoke to Allegra Goodman about her book.
I've worked in a research lab and I think you've done a remarkably accurate portrait of what it's like to work in one.
What drew - what drew you to this subject?
I was drawn to the subject in part by jealousy because I'm a writer who works alone.
And my husband is a computer scientist who works with other people.
And my sister's an oncologist, my brother-in-law's a computational biologist, and all of the scientists in my life are always bouncing ideas off of one another and collaborating with each other.
And I got fascinated by the idea of collaborative work relationships.
And I decided to focus on a biological research lab.
But it's interesting because you pointed your lens at something which people assume is uncommon, which is scientific misconduct.
Why that direction?

Well you know, it's funny, I could say that just as a scientist often studies the organism in crisis or the disease organism in order the, you know, the actual structure of the cell, you know, so I studied a lab in crisis in which one person accuses another of misconduct, of fraud, fraudulent results.
I became very interested in those issues of trust and doubt and betrayal in this book.
So basically the book revolves around a character named Cliff who is a post-doc working in a lab and he's come up with a virus that seems to be curing mice of cancer.
And the controversy starts when another post-doc whom he used to date, or was dating, sees his work and thinks he's done something fraudulent.
Is that right?
That's right.
She thinks that his results are too good to be true.
She begins to doubt him.
But my question is, he did get results.
I mean in, in your novel, Cliff actually...
Yeah.
...does cure mice, or seems to.
Their tumors go away because of this virus...
Yes.
...that he's created.
So he's done something and yet he's also done something wrong, it seems.
Yes.
I think the issue is that he gets some excellent results but that they are not as dramatic as he makes them appear in his publication.
So it's sort of a - it's a question of which data he selected.

Is it your intention to talk about the enthusiasm with which the lab directors embrace, or at least one of them, embraces the work and carries it forward and uses it to get grant money and builds his career on it?
Because that's a big part of the book as well.
Come on.
I've answered it more times than you have this year.
Maybe I could do it faster.
What do you want...
You can do it faster.
A new report on the mental health of Hurricane Katrina survivors contains some surprising information.
The study's author says what's going on in the Gulf Coast is contrary to the patterns usually seen after major disasters.
And we have more this morning from NPR's Alix Spiegel.

They released three CDs.
And this isn't Beethoven's bassoon.

How about Hendrix?

And then there's Ben Wendel.
When he's not playing the sax, he's jazzing it up on the bassoon.

We're like the Illuminati of the jazz world or something.

They call themselves the Breaking Winds.
